topic.title: Initialize the Cluster
topic.shortdesc: Following installation, the Couchbase cluster must be initialized. You can achieve this by means of the any of the following utilities: the Couchbase Web Console; the Couchbase Command Line Interface; or the Couchbase REST API. Instructions for each are provided in this section.

section.title: Access the Couchbase Web Console
section.p: The Couchbase Web Console is, by default, available on port 8091. Therefore, if your machine can be identified on the network as servera, you can access the Couchbase Web Console by opening http://servera:8091/. Alternatively, you can use an IP address or, if you are working on the machine on which installation was performed, http://localhost:8091. If you have chosen to run Couchbase on a port other than 8091, connect on that specific port.
Once you have connected, to begin setting up Couchbase Server, click the Setup button on the Welcome Screen:
The Welcome Screen lets you choose either to Setup New Cluster, or to Join Existing Cluster. Left-click on Setup New Cluster. This brings up the New Cluster screen.
(Note that information on joining an existing cluster is provided below, in the section Join an Existing Cluster

section.title: Set Up a New Cluster
section.p: The New Cluster screen appears as follows:
The displayed fields for New Cluster are as follows:

ul.li: Cluster Name: An administrator-chosen name for the cluster to be created.

Create Admin Username: An administrator-chosen username, for the Full Administrator (which is to say, the current administrator) for this cluster. You will have read-write access to all Couchbase Server resources; including the ability to create new users with defined roles and corresponding privileges.
Note that Couchbase Server prohibits use of the following characters in usernames: ( ) < > @ , ; : \ " / [ ] ? = { }.

An administrator-chosen password, for the Full Administrator on this cluster. This only default requirement is that the password be at least 6 characters in length. Note that the default password-policy can be modified (and indeed, strengthened), by means of the Couchbase CLI setting-password-policy command.

section.p: When you have entered appropriate data into each field, left-click on the Next: Accept Terms button, at the lower right.

section.title: Accept Terms
section.p: The content of the New Cluster screen now changes, to show the Terms and Conditions for the Enterprise Edition of Couchbase Server:

Check the I accept the terms & conditions checkbox. Then, to register for updates, left-click on the right-facing arrowhead, adjacent to the Register for updates notification. The screen now expands vertically, as follows:

To receive updates, fill out the four new fields as appropriate. If you elect to do so, provided that the current node is connected to the internet, the Couchbase Server version-numbers corresponding to each node in your cluster will be anonymously sent to Couchbase: this information is used by Couchbase over time, to provide you with appropriate updates, and to help with product-improvement. Your email-address will be added to the Couchbase community mailing-list, so that you can periodically receive Couchbase news and product-information. (You can unsubscribe from the mailing-list at any time using the Unsubscribe link, provided in each newsletter.)

You now have two options for proceeding. If you left-click on the Finish With Defaults button, cluster-initialization is performed with default settings, provided by Couchbase. If you wish to configure those settings, left-click on the Configure Disk, Memory, Services button. This brings up the Configure screen, as described below.

section.title: Configure Couchbase Server
section.p: The Configure screen appears as follows:
The fields are described below:

ul.li: Host Name / IP Address: the hostname or IP address for the machine on which you are configuring Couchbase Server.

Data Disk Path: The interactive text-field should contain the location on the current node where the database files will be stored. The following default is provided: /Users/username/Library/Application Support/Couchbase/var/lib/couchbase/data. The read-only Free field shows the current amount of free space for this location.

Indexes Disk Path: The interactive text-field should contain the location on the current node where indices will be stored. The following default is provided: /Users/username/Library/Application Support/Couchbase/var/lib/couchbase/data. The read-only Free field shows the current amount of free space for this location.
Note that for a production environment, it is recommended that data and indexes should not share the same location.

Couchase Memory Quotas: A series of fields that allows you to specify how much memory should be allocated to each service you select for both the current node and for each node you may subsequently add to the cluster. Each service can be selected by means of checking a checkbox, and then specifying the total number of megabytes to be assigned to it. In each case, a memory quota is suggested, and a minimum quota is required. The sum of all quotas must be within the total amount of available RAM for the current node.
Data Service (data & views): Since you are starting a new cluster, the Data service (which is essential for the cluster) has been allocated with its checkbox disabled. If this is a development system, you may add up to three services. Note that on a production system, it is recommended that only one service ever be allocated per node.
GSI Service: Selection and RAM-allocation for GSI Service. This should be 256 MB or more. If this service is selected, a default quota is provided.
FTS Service : Selection and RAM-allocation for the Full Text Service. This should be 256 MB or more. If this service is selected, a default quota is provided.
Query Service : Note that no RAM-allocation is required for the Query Service.
The total memory quota you have allocated is displayed below these fields, towards the right. The total RAM available is displayed below this figure, at the center. If your memory allocation is excessive, a notification warns you, and you must re-allocate.

Index Storage Setting: If the Index service has been selected, either Standard Global Secondary Indexes or Memory-Optimized Global Secondary Indexes can be chosen here, by means of radio buttons. See , for details.
Check the checkbox for Enable software update notifications in the web console, if appropriate.

section.p: When you are finished entering your configuration-details, left-click on the Save & Finish button, at the lower right. This configures the server accordingly, and brings up the Couchbase Web Console Dashboard, for the first time.

section.title: Join an Existing Cluster
section.p: If you left-click on Join Existing Clouster, the Join Cluster screen appears:

The fields Cluster Host Name/IP Address, Cluster Admin Username, and Cluster Admin Password require information defined by the Full Administrator for the cluster-host: see Set Up a New Cluster, above.

When you have entered the appropriate details, you can left-click on the Join With Default Configuration button, at the lower right, in order to join the cluster with a default configuration. Note that the default configuration is not recommended for production environments.To change that configuration, or to review its details, left-click on the right-pointing arrowhead adjacent to the Configure Services & Settings For This Node notification.
The screen now expands vertically, as follows:

Newly display fields show default values for the four Couchbase services (with each box checked, indicating that each will be added to this node by default), the Host Name/IP Address for the current node, and the paths for Data and Indexes paths.

Note that the checkboxes for the four services are not accompanied by fields whereby memory quotas might be specified: this is because such quotas are expected already to have been specified by the Full Administrator (for example, during configuration of the principal cluster-host). However, in some circumstances, node-addition may feature addition of a service not previously configured: in which case memory-quota specification is required. For example, uncheck the checkboxes for Query Service and FTS Service. The checkboxes now appear as follows:
Note that due to this change, the button at the lower right has been renamed:
Left-click on this button, to save the configurations you have specified. The New Service Settings dialog now appears:

This dialog acknowledges that the GSI Index has been added to the cluster for the first time, and provides the opportunity to edit both services now added (Data and GSI), and to provide a new selection for the Index Storage Setting. Note that the modifications you make are applied to each node in the cluster. When you have made the appropriate changes, left-click on the Save Settings button. The Couchbase Web Console Dashboard for the current node now appears — with a notification indicating the successful saving of a new memory quota:
The new node has now been successfully added to the existing cluster.

section.title: Install Sample Buckets
section.p: Couchbase provides sample buckets, which contain data for demonstration and test purposes. The Sample Buckets screen allows you to choose which of these buckets you wish to install. The screen appears as follows:

Check the corresponding checkboxes for the sample buckets you wish to to load into the Couchbase Server. Then, click the Next button. This dismisses the Sample Buckets screen, and displays the Create Default Bucket screen.

section.title: Create a Default Bucket
section.p: Creation of a default bucket is optional. The bucket contains no data by default; but can be configured in detail, and used for testing and other purposes. It can be removed after installation, if appropriate; and can be re-added still later.

The Create Default Bucket screen allows a Name and Memory Quota for the default bucket to be established. The current Cluster quota is represented — along with current allocations for Other Buckets, This Bucket, and Free memory — by the horizontal display-bar.

Additionally, the Create Default Bucket screen provides advanced settings, which are accessed by left-clicking on the Show advanced bucket settings tab. The tab is expanded, and the screen appears as follows:
The advanced settings are described below.

li.p: The type of the bucket can be established as Couchbase, Memcached, or Ephemeral, by means of radio-buttons. Couchbase is initially selected by default. If you select Memcached, the appearance of the Create Default Bucket screen changes to the following:
As shown by the above illustration, the Replicas and Disk I/O Optimization sections have been omitted; since they are not pertinent to memcached buckets.

If you click Ephemeral, the screen is identical to that for Couchbase buckets, with two exceptions: first, ejection-options are No Eviction and NRU Eviction, rather than Value-only and Full; secondly, the Replicate view indexes option is omitted. These options are all described below.
Ejection Method options differ between Couchbase and Ephemeral buckets.

For Couchbase buckets, the options are Value-only and Full. If Full is selected, everything (including data, metadata, key, and value) is ejected. If Value-only is selection, only data is ejected. Generally, Value-only Ejection favors performance at the expense of memory; and Full Ejection vice versa. See , for more information. Note that ejection means removal from memory, with continued persistence on disk.

For Ephemeral buckets, the options are No Eviction and NRU Eviction. If No Eviction is selected, no eviction of existing data occurs, and attempts to cache new data fail. If NRU Eviction is selected, existing data is evicted, with Not Recently Used documents being those removed. Note that eviction means removal from memory without persistence (since ephemeral buckets have no presence on disk): thus, removal is absolute.

A conflict occurs during XDCR, when a document has been modified in different ways in different locations; so necessitating that one of the versions be chosen for retention, and the other discarded. There are two methods for making this choice; represented by the Sequence number and Timestamp checkboxes. The method you choose is permanently established for the current bucket: it cannot subsequently be changed. For information on the significance of each method, see XDCR Conflict Resolution.
Note that you can also set the conflict resolution method using the CLI command, or the REST API.

This section allows replica-creation to be enabled and managed. To enable, check the Enable checkbox. The number of replica-copies to be created and maintained is determined by means of the Number of replica (backup) copies pulldown menu, which allows a value from 1 to 3 to be selected.
The Replicate view indexes checkbox is available for Couchbase buckets only: by checking it, you ensure that view indexes, as well as data, are replicated: see , for details.

For Couchbase buckets, this section allows you to specify the priority of the current bucket's background tasks, relative to the background tasks of other buckets on the cluster. Background tasks may involve disk I/O, DCP stream-processing, item-paging, and more.

Radio-buttons allow Low or High to be chosen. These settings determine whether the bucket's tasks are enqueued in low or high priority task-queues. The default is Low. Specifying High may result in faster processing for the current bucket's tasks. However, the specification only makes a difference when there is more than one bucket defined for the cluster, and when defined buckets have differing settings. See , for further information.
This section allows flushing to be enabled. If it is enabled, and flushing is performed, items in the bucket are removed as soon as possible. See , for details.

section.p: If you do not wish to configure and use the Default Bucket, click on the Skip button. If you do wish to use it, once you have entered your configuration-preferences, click on the Next button.
The Create Default Bucket setup screen is now dismissed, and the Notifications screen appears.

section.title: Enable Notifications
section.p: The Notifications screen features two key areas, which are as follows:

li.p: If you check the Enable software update notifications checkbox, provided that the current node is connected to the internet, the Couchbase Server version-numbers corresponding to each node in your cluster will be anonymously sent to Couchbase: this information is used by Couchbase over time, to provide you with appropriate updates, and to help with product-improvement. If you additionally choose (based on other fields in this dialog, described immediately below) to provide registration-information, your email-address will be added to the Couchbase community mailing-list, so that you can periodically receive Couchbase news and product-information. (You can unsubscribe from the mailing-list at any time using the Unsubscribe link, provided in each newsletter.)
Register your product, by entering your Email, First name, Last name, and Comapny. Then, check the checkbox whereby you agree to accept terms and conditions.

section.p: When you have finished entering information, click on the Next button. This dismisses the Notifications screen, and displays the Configure Server screen.

section.title: Configure Server
section.p: To create a cluster, you must assign yourself administrative credentials: these will be used on all nodes in the cluster you are creating. This is accomplished by means of the Configure Server screen:

Enter an appropriate username (this defaults to Administrator), and a password; and then verify the password. Note that this process makes you a full administrator, with read-write access to all areas of the Couchbase Server-system; including production-data and security-settings, whereby additional administrators and applications can be assigned roles and corresponding credentials. See RBAC for Administrators and Applications, for detailed information.
Then, click on the Next button.

section.title: Explore Couchbase Server
section.p: Couchbase Server is now running and ready for use. The Dashboard for the new Couchbase Server now appears, as follows:

Using the Couchbase Web Console, you can now explore all the administrative options at your disposal, by means of the vertical navigation-bar, at the left. For example, by left-clicking on the Buckets tab, you can examine the data-contents of whatever buckets you previously installed:

section.title: Initialize the Cluster Using the CLI
section.p: Rather than using the Couchbase Web Console, you may elect to initialize your Couchbase cluster by means of the Couchbase CLI (Command Line Interface).

The following CLI syntax can be used for initial set-up of a single-node Couchbase Server-cluster. It allows the establishing of administrative credentials, and of port number. It adds all services; sets separate RAM quotas for Data, Index, and Search services, and sets the index storage-option (the default being to support memory-optimized global indexes):
section.codeblock: couchbase-cli cluster-init OPTIONS: --cluster-username=USER // new admin username --cluster-password=PASSWORD // new admin password --cluster-port=PORT // new cluster REST/http port --services=data,index,query,fts // services that server runs --cluster-ramsize=RAMSIZEMB // per node data service ram quota in MB --cluster-index-ramsize=RAMSIZEMB // per node index service ram quota in MB --cluster-fts-ramsize=RAMSIZEMB // per node index service ram quota in MB --index-storage-setting=SETTING // index storage type [default, memopt]

section.title: Initialize the Cluster Using the REST API
section.p: The third option for performing Couchbase cluster-initialization is provided by the Couchbase REST API.
The following REST API examples are used to set up a single-node Couchbase Server cluster with three services, administrative credentials, and a RAM quota:

sectiondiv.codeblock: curl -u [admin-name]:[password] -v -X POST http://[localhost]:8091/node/controller/setupServices -d services=[kv | index | n1ql | fts]
sectiondiv.p: Set up your administrator-username and password:
Set up the index RAM quota (to be applied across the entire cluster):
sectiondiv.codeblock: curl -u username=[admin-name]&password=[password] -X POST http://[localhost]:8091/pools/default -d memoryQuota=[value] -d indexMemoryQuota=[value]

// Set up a bucket.
curl -u Administrator:password -v -X POST http://192.168.42.101:8091/pools/\ default/buckets -d 'flushEnabled=1&threadsNumber=3&replicaIndex\ =0&replicaNumber=0&evictionPolicy= valueOnly&ramQuotaMB=597&\ bucketType=membase&name=default&authType=sasl&saslPassword='
